node.title: Modifying the tutorial codes from RACCOON
node.bodyText:
Hi
I am a new user of Moose and RACCOON (A parallel finite-element code specialized in phase-field for fracture) and I am currently making simulations of crack and crack growth using phase field. I am using the tutorial code from RACCOON that is named "Tutorial 2: Mode-I crack propagation" where the full code can be found in "tutorials/mode1_brittle_fracture/elasticity.i". In that code the package
[elasticity]
type = SmallDeformationIsotropicElasticity
is used, and I'm wondering if it is possible to modify it to Anisotropic elasticity instead?
If so, what is the other module called? and how does it affect the rest of the code? and how do I apply it?
I have looked through the library of RACOON but didn't find anything "anisotropy" related.
I appreciate any help I can get.

@hugary1995 will know more than me but to go from IsotropicElasticity to an anisotropic model, you just need to find the model that does not specify that it s isotropic.
So here, maybe look for SmallDeformationElasticity, and if it doesn't exist, look for a similar model in the phase field module

Thanks for your relpy.
I found this, https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ComputeElasticityTensor.html , where it shows how to compute different kinds of elasticity tensors. The problem is that I am new to moose and phase field in general so when I tried to modify the codes "elasticity.i" and "fracture.i", it resulted in bunch of errors since changing/adding in one part of the code, you need to change/add something else in another part of the code.

RACCOON currently doesn't support anisotropic elasticity.

Bad news: You will have to write code to do that, which requires some basic knowledge of C++.
Good news: It will be a straightforward extension.
Bad news: I currently don't have the bandwidth to do that for you. So you are on your own, though I'd be happy to help along the way.

So, if you accept the challenge, show me your equations first, and then I can tell you which files to modify/adapt.

Thank you so much for your assistance!
I have no background in C++ and I can only program in python and matlab, so it will be difficult for me to implement a new code. So instead I'm wondering if it is possible to modify the mode1_brittle_fracture code so it instead applies cyclic loading?
Or maybe change the angle on how the force is applied  in order to see how the fracture changes?
Are those things possible in RACCOON?
Yes, these are possible. In fact, these are regular tasks handled by MOOSE, so I recommend you to go through the MOOSE tutorials first.
Thanks, will do.
what is the update on anisotropy in raccoon?

node.title: Query about coupling function with the PropertyReadFile for both temporal and spatial changes
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Dear Moose Users,
I am now trying to simulate cracking at varying temperatures using a phase-field model, in which I want to set that the critical energy release rate Gc is not uniformly distributed in the RVE and changing along with temperature increase.
Firstly I am assigning Gc into the RVE by PropertyReadFile in UserObjects, in the .txt file the G_c is assigned to each element seperately:
> [UserObjects]
>   [./Gc_read]
>     type = ElementPropertyReadFile
>     prop_file_name = 'non_linear.txt'
>     nprop = 1
>     read_type = element
>   [../]
> []


while in the Materials block, I introduce G_c as (gc_prop_read is added in [AuxVariables] ):
  [./Gc_from_file_object]
    type = FileParsedMaterial
    prop_name = 'gc_prop_read'
    read_prop_user_object = Gc_read
  [../] 

Then in the Functions block I want to implement the temperature dependence of this G_c:
[Functions]
  [./temperature_Gc]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '1.8*(x-300)/356'
  [../]
[]

My goal is to let the Gc of each element following this temperature function (temperature is changing at different steps following another function), but still keep the spatial dfiference given by the initial value from the read .txt file.
I tried to use this method in the [Materials] block, but it seems not working:
  [./Gc_scale]
    type = CoupledValueFunctionMaterial
    function = temperature_Gc
    v = 'temp'
    prop_name = gc_prop_read
  [../]  

Also I tried  DerivativeParsedMaterial, which is also not working well.
Could you please give some suggestions on this issue?

Hello
What do you mean by it seems it's not working?
What error do you get with the CoupledVariableFunctionMateeial?
And what about with the DericativeParsedMaterial?
Guillaume

Hi,
Thank you for your prompt reply.
Actually I did not meet errors when using them. I can find the Gc are correctly distributed in the RVE as expected. But when temperature changes they did not change together, so I guess the coupling between function and propertyreadfile is not right. I want to know whether I am on a right way  to solve it in [Materials] like this or should use other methods instead.
Thank you!
Best regards,
Daijun

Hi Guillaume,
Sorry that I should provide more information for my query.
As mentioned above I made a [Gc_scale] block, where I made the temperature dependence of Gc into a scale factor.
This factor is transfered to an auxvariable called gc_scale, while the read gc initial values are stored to another auxvariable gc_read.
  [./Gc_scale]
    type = CoupledValueFunctionMaterial
    function = temperature_Gc
    v = 'temp'
    prop_name = gc_prop_scale
  [../]  
  [./Gc_from_file_object]
    type = FileParsedMaterial
    prop_name = 'gc_prop_read'
    read_prop_user_object = Gc_read
  [../] 

Then my questions goes to how to combine them together to a final gc_prop which is needed for my fracture modeling.
I firstly tried ParsedMaterial like:
  [./Gc_temp_map]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    expression = 'gc_prop_scale *gc_prop_read'
    coupled_variables= 'gc_prop_scale  gc_prop_read'
    property_name = gc_prop
  [../] 

But it shows that  ERROR: FunctionParser is unable to parse expression: gc_prop_scale * gc_prop_read
Then I tried CoupledValueeFunctionMaterial by adding a function Gc_calculation:
  [./Gc_calculation]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = 'x*y'
  [../]
  [./Gc_temp_map]
    type = CoupledValueFunctionMaterial
    function = Gc_calculation
    v = 'gc_prop_scale  gc_prop_read'
    prop_name = gc_prop
  [../] 

It shows no error but not working to give the temperature dependence to Gc. In my opinion this is close and I am also checking the tempearture files used for this method. For my this coupling issue is that the temperature is changing with time, Gc is both temperature dependent and spatially different in each element as assigned.
The DerivativeParsedMaterial is not a right way I think, because currently no derivative is included.
I look forward to your suggestions on using which type for this kind of coupling. If the CoupledValueFunctionMaterial is a correct way, i will check other parts of my input file. Thank you in advance and will keep you updated.
Best regards,
Daijun

hello
  [./Gc_temp_map]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    expression = 'gc_prop_scale *gc_prop_read'
    coupled_variables= 'gc_prop_scale  gc_prop_read'
    property_name = gc_prop
  [../] 

this is not quite right since gc_prop_scale  and gc_prop_read are not variables, they are material properties
so it should be
material_property_names = 'gc_prop_scale  gc_prop_read'

instead

Dear Guillaume,
Yes that is the point. I have tried and this made it work.
Thank you!

Hi, it is good that you are using GrainTracker, but you should be able to use fewer than 17 OPs. Try 8-10 for 2D. Also check your adaptivity setting to make sure you are not over-resolving the interfaces. You need about 3 elements through the interface between grains.
I would start from the example input file moose/modules/phase_field/examples/grain_growth/grain_growth_2D_graintracker.i in the example and slowly make changes starting from this. I think this will be easier than trying to profile the code for your file. Try increasing the size and number of grains by a factor of 2 starting from this input file rather than trying to dramatically increasing the problem size and number of cores all at once. This will make it easier to identify issues.

[]

[UserObjects]
  [voronoi]
    type = PolycrystalVoronoi
    grain_num = 6400 # Number of grains
    rand_seed = 2878
    coloring_algorithm = jp
    int_width = 3.46
  []
  [grain_tracker]
    type = GrainTracker
    verbosity_level = 0
    compute_var_to_feature_map = true
  []
[]

From what you have shown here, you'd have 1000 elements in each direction, starting from 250 elements and refining twice. That would give a mesh size of 2000 /  1000 = 2.0 in the x and y directions. This would be a little too coarse for interface width of 3.46. You would want at least 3 elements through the interface so probably at least 1 more level of refinement at the interfaces, adaptive meshing would work well to give you that.
That said 6400 is A LOT of grains even for 2D. You are likely going to need a lot more cores. Best performance will be obtained at 20,000 DOF/core. It's very time consuming to troubleshoot performance and adaptivity for large simulations, which is why I strongly suggest to start with a much smaller problem and make sure your settings are working correctly before doing something this large.

BAsed on the usage of cores, 1 core for 20000
my system has following DOFs
Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                28774217
  Num Local DOFs:          82654
  Num Constrained DOFs:    44217
  Local Constrained DOFs:  0
  Variables:               { "gr0" "gr1" "gr2" "gr3" "gr4" ... "gr12" "gr13" "gr14" "gr15" "gr16" }
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE"
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST"

Auxiliary System:
  Num DOFs:                6762601
  Num Local DOFs:          18947
  Num Constrained DOFs:    2601
  Local Constrained DOFs:  0
  Variables:               "bnds" { "unique_grains" "var_indices" "phi" }
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE" "MONOMIAL"
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" "CONSTANT"

that means I have to use ~1438 cores to run this simulation. Is it correct? That is seriously high number of cores I need.
Well you can reduce that by at least half if you use fewer order parameters
I have tried that but 17 is the minimum OP I can get the simulation started. if I am using even finer mesh then the simulation terminates with out of memory issue.

you dont "need" it. It s just the expected scalability limit
Having less is fine
The advice on reducing the order parameter is what you should look into
ok I will see what changes I can make. Thank you

Can you post an image of your initial microstructure? Images both with and without the mesh superimposed on top would be helpful. Trying to understand why you are needing such a large number of order parameters

As previously mentioned, you will want more elements across the interfaces, right now the interfaces are under-resolved and you are not going to properly resolve the physics of grain growth. The interfaces are also pretty wide relative to the size of the grains in some places, usually you want the grain size to be at least 10x larger than the interface width (although some variation in initial conditions makes this hard to achieve uniformly). Both of these factors could be part of the reason why you are needing more order parameters than usual.
Again I would highly suggest that you start with a much smaller problem and make sure all your settings and parameters are working properly before trying to run something this large.

okay I get it now. that my mesh grids are not large enough. The number of grains are for a particular reason. The friction pressure model that I am working on need to have theses number of grains to see the pinning effect. So I will try to increase the resolution. I will get back to you with the update. thank you very much

Hello,

[]

Just curious. Thanks

Hello, do you think GPU will help me do this large simulations? Are there any input files that I can look into?
Thank you
we are working on it. There is nothing ready right now for this

ok. I think that would have helped me. I was looking at a paper (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.commatsci.2020.109992)
"The domain was divided into a grid of 2560 × 2560 × 2560 by regular cubic lattices with a size of Δx = 1. The system consisted of 3,125,000 grains that are under periodic boundary conditions in all directions.
.
.
.
All simulations were carried out on the GPU-rich supercomputer TSUBAME3.0 at the Tokyo Institute of Technology by utilizing our own parallel GPU code (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927025620304833#b0330). The number of GPUs (NVIDIA Tesla P100) used for each simulation was 256."
That is a VERY LARGE system.
Looking forward to the GPU based input parameters.
Thank you

node.title: Mismatching block-restrictions are specified for variable with name 'disp_x':
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello
I updated MOOSE. The new version seems to remove block-restrictions on variables. So that the simulation that could have been performed earlier reported errors. An example is as follows:
[Problem]
  kernel_coverage_check = false
  material_coverage_check = false
  boundary_restricted_node_integrity_check = false
  # boundary_restricted_elem_integrity_check = false
[]

new_domain_blocks = '1001    1002'

[Mesh]
  [box]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    nx = 10
    ny = 10
    nz = 10
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 1
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 1
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 1
  []
  [box1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = box
    block_id = 1
    bottom_left = '0 0.5 0'
    top_right = '1 1 1'
  []

  add_subdomain_ids = '${new_domain_blocks}'
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  []
  [disp_y]
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  []
  [disp_z]
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  []
[]

# ===== Tensor mechanics for all active domain blocks =====
[Physics]
  [SolidMechanics]
    [QuasiStatic]
      [all]
        strain = finite
        block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
        add_variables = true
        generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_zz'
      []
    []
  []
[]

# ===== Gravity =====
[Kernels]
  [Gravity1]
    type = Gravity
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
    use_displaced_mesh = false
    variable = disp_y
    value = -10
  []
[]

# ===== Boundary Conditions =====

    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'bottom'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []

    boundary = 'bottom'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [archor_z]

    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
  []
[]

# ===== Materials (linear-elastic to keep it simple) =====

    times = '200 300'
    blocks_from = '0 1'
    blocks_to = '1001    1002'

node.bodyText:

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question

 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello，
I refined part of the mesh. Apply pressure to the top. The results looked a little strange. The refined mesh seems to be separated from the unrefined mesh. What causes this? Are there any good suggestions for this problem?
The initial mesh, the refined mesh and the results are as follows:

mesh and result
initial mesh

refined mesh

result

Hello
your initial mesh is not attached (not conformal). It does not improve with refinement.
You can see it where you drew your first red circle in the first page
The initial mesh is the first diagram. This is the mesh refined from the upper part of the initial mesh.

I know

The refined mesh seems to be separated from the unrefined mesh

it was already separated in the initial mesh.
I dont know what you used for mesh generation but it did not attach the top and bottom parts. Otherwise on the left and right of the first pictures we would see nodes being shared by both parrts
The initial mesh is not separated. The first image looks separated because of the Angle of the screenshot. It actually looks like this:

what do the mesh diagnostics say?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/MeshDiagnosticsGenerator.html
Thank you for your answer. I figured out what the problem was.

node.title: Cohesive Zone Analysis: FEM Solution is not a smooth curve
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
In cohesive zone method, I am trying to generate traction vs separation plot for mode-II loading. However the plot that I am getting is not a smooth curve. I am comparing it with the analytical plot of the traction separation law.

Can someone help what may be the reason. I have already played with the 'viscosity' parameter under CZM material.
Following is my input file:



@arovinelli @jiangwen84 @GiudGiud
Is it something to do with the solver controls in executioner?

Hello
This looks almost correct. Just a little bit of oscillations to remove.
What does the convergence history look like? In the log of one of the noisy points.
Is there any nested solve in a material property that could be less converged?

What does the convergence history look like?
--> I am attaching the solution history somewhere between 1.6 seconds to 4 seconds when the curve has just started to drop in the first softening region.




Just a little bit of oscillations to remove.
-->Yes I want to remove those oscillations. I want the FEM solution curve to be smooth. Because for other similar problems the oscillation are causing significant result difference. I am attaching a curve for one such comparative analysis. See the following:



Is there any nested solve in a material property that could be less converged?
I did not understand this part. However please see the script that I have attached.


Thanks for your interest.

Oh I did not realize this was a single transient.
Then the oscillations could be coming from the time integration scheme. You are using the default 1st order implicit Euler. Let's try BDF2 (scheme = bdf2 in the Executioner)
except there is no time derivative term. So it's not that.

I did try using scheme = bdf2 in the executioner.
But the results are exactly same. No change.
